author: Danielle Smith
title: Criminal justice reform would boost MS workforce, economy
text: Criminal justice reform would boost MS workforce, economy Tuesday, January 2, 2024 In the new year, advancing [criminal justice reform](https://www.fwd.us/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/MS-Workforce-Brief.pdf) could improve the Magnolia State's low labor participation rate and strengthen the workforce, according to a group advocating for reform. Mississippi's [incarceration rate](https://www.prisonpolicy.org/profiles/MS.html) is the highest in the country. Alesha Judkins, Mississippi state director of criminal justice reform for the nonprofit FWD.us, said the state can do more to remove barriers to employment for people out of prison. Judkins pointed out just 54% of working age-adults are actively seeking jobs, and too many sit out the search because they have criminal convictions. "As our state leaders are looking at our workforce in the economy, trying to deal with jobs, at the time we released this report it was reported about 85,000 job openings in the state," Judkins explained. "I think now it's around 80,000. But only 40,000 people actively seeking employment, right? So, for every job opening, there is, like, two people needed." Judkins noted Mississippi taxpayers spend more than $400 million a year to run the state prison system, which she argued comes without a strong public safety return on their investment. She contended if Mississippi imprisoned people at the rates of neighboring states, it could save $220 million a year. Judkins emphasized having a criminal record often leads to underemployment or unemployment, slashing earning potential by an estimated 50%. It also hinders their ability to support local businesses, and the state also faces economic consequences. "Mississippi residents are losing out on about $2.7 billion in earnings due to their criminal records," Judkins stressed. "At least half of those earnings would likely be spent on things like food, clothing, and transportation, all of which are subject to sales tax. And as a result, the state is losing an estimated $95 million in tax revenue every year." She acknowledged the state is already finding some ways to reduce its prison population and get more people employed upon release. In 2021, the Legislature [expanded parole eligibility](https://billstatus.ls.state.ms.us/2021/pdf/history/SB/SB2795.xml) and the state is also providing assistance with driver's licenses. author: Times Of India
title: City breathes easy as rain washes air clean | Ludhiana News - Times of India
text: Ludhiana: For a change, air in the city is light and refreshing. With rain over the last two days washing away dirt and grime, residents breathed the cleanest air in the last over two months. According to the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) bulletin of Thursday, air quality index (measure of air quality in an area) in Ludhiana was recorded at 45, which falls under the good air quality bracket with minimal impact on health.Last time AQI in Ludhiana was less than Thursday’s value was on April 30, when it was recorded at 42. It was second lowest on July 3, when it was recorded at 63 (moderate category). Highest AQI in the last more than two months in Ludhiana was 241 on on June 5 (poor air quality bracket).111499857 Ludhiana was at third position in the state in terms of AQI on Thursday. Rupnagar had the lowest AQI of 27, followed by Patiala with AQI of 33. Amritsar had the highest AQI among cities of the state on Thursday. Punjab Pollution Control Board (PPCB) officials said that the rain had washed away pollutants in the air, bringing AQI down. They also said that once rainfall decreased, air quality would deteriorate again due to vehicular traffic, commercial activity and construction works.Meanwhile, many residents said that they would want a permanent solution to the problem of air pollution in the city. Narinder Singh, a city resident said that instead of rejoicing over a temporary improvement, they wanted a permanent solution. He said that government departments and residents had to come together and work towards this. He also underlined the need to enhance the city’s green cover. author: Mirage News
title: McCormack's Advocacy Ends Push For Yass Solar Factory | Mirage News
text:
Nationals Member for Riverina, Michael McCormack, has welcomed a decision by energy producer ENGIE to drop plans to build a massive solar factory on the outskirts of Yass.
Mr McCormack said he told ENGIE that land designated for the project - less than two kilometres from the Yass post office and targeted for up to 240,000 solar panels - was valuable agricultural country which needed to be retained.
"About 340 hectares of farmland - a footprint larger than the town itself - was earmarked for the project," Mr McCormack said.
Mr McCormack said the planned site of the solar factory was virtually on the doorstep of some residents, while other people faced the prospect of looking down on a sea of black solar panels and a three-metre high security fence surrounding the solar panels every time they walked out their front or back door.
Mr McCormack listened to the concerns of residents at a meeting at Yass in February and has been making consistent representations on their behalf to ENGIE ever since.
"I was moved by their very real worries, including a loss of views and plummeting property values," Mr McCormack said.
"I was told at least one property could not be sold because of the solar factory plans, while there were very real fears about safety on Perry Street, a narrow road with a three-tonne load limit, which would be used by heavy trucks six days a week for 18 months to two years during construction.
"There were also fears about chemicals used to clean solar panels leaching into creeks on the site and ending up in the nearby Yass River and toxic fumes sweeping over Yass should a fire break out and panels were burnt."
"I don't think these many serious concerns could be addressed satisfactorily and told ENGIE so."
Mr McCormack said ENGIE would now undertake a feasibility study on putting a large-scale battery on the site which would be connected to nearby electricity transmission lines to help secure electricity supply.

author: Ariel Velázquez
title: Aaron Leinhardt es el nuevo hombre responsable de la analítica de los New York Yankees - AS USA
text: Aaron Judge frotó la lámpara mágica y el genio apareció para cumplir sus deseos. A principios de octubre del año pasado, apenas unos cuantos días después de que la temporada de los New York Yankees terminó sin su primer viaje a playoffs desde 2016, Judge, capitán de los Bronx Bombers concedió una entrevista en donde prácticamente urgió a la directiva a hacer cambios en la forma en la que estaban analizando el juego. El Juez, conocido como un pelotero políticamente correcto y sin ningún escándalo que ensucie su carrera, dejó de lado los mensajes entre líneas y optó la claridad de la palabra. “Creo que se trata simplemente de cómo usamos [los análisis] y cómo los valoramos, es un aspecto que tal vez debamos revisar nuevamente. No diría que [estamos] sobrecargados. Creo que es simplemente mirar los números correctos. Creo que tal vez estemos mirando a los equivocados. Necesitamos valorar algunos otros que la gente podría considerar que no tienen valor” dijo Judge en esa ocasión. Mientras el cañonero Juan Soto capturó los reflectores al convertirse en la gran adquisición de los Yankees durante el invierno, detrás del telón, la oficina neoyorquina revisó múltiples curriculum para encontrar a la persona que pudiera cumplir con los deseos de su capitán. A pesar de la extensa búsqueda, la respuesta la obtuvieron dentro de casa. Los Yankees decidieron ascender a Aaron Leanhardt, un físico del Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), quien se encontraba dentro de la organización desde 2018, aunque con cargos con poco impacto. “Estoy entusiasmado con él”, dijo Judge a The New York Post esta semana. “Él está en un buen papel, siendo ese analista que es la barrera entre nosotros y los análisis. Lo que he visto hasta ahora es que hace un buen trabajo canalizando la información. Creo que a los muchachos les va a encantar”. Antes de involucrarse con los Yankees, Leanhardt ya tenía algo que decir sobre beisbol, aunque su experiencia correspondía más al lenguaje científico. En MIT trabajó en una investigación financiada por la NASA en la que logró enfriar un gas de sodio a la temperatura más baja jamás registrada. Es difícil descifrar si ese estudio tendrá alguna repercusión en los Yankees, pero Judge no tiene dudas sobre el tipo de persona que ahora está al frente del análisis del equipo. “Definitivamente es el tipo más inteligente aquí. Todavía no ha mostrado su Premio Nobel”, bromeó Judge. “Creo que lo guardará para una buena reunión o algo así”. TAL VEZ TE PUEDE INTERESAR: Los Yankees cuidan con recelo al clon de Aaron Judge Como dijimos anteriomente, Leanhardt no es ningún improvisado dentro de la industria de Major League Baseball. Comenzó su carrera como entrenador en 2017, haciendo paradas en Nueva Jersey (asistente en la Atlantic Collegiate Baseball League) y Montana (entrenador de bateo y coordinador de reclutamiento en Dawson Community College). Aaron se encargaba principalmente de aportar su conocimiento en las prácticas de bateo. Antes de que Leanhardt tomara la silla principal de analista de los Yankees, ese puesto lo ocupaba Zax Fieroh, quien fue trasladado a otra área para darle la oportunidad a Aaron de emerger. “Tiene una gran ética de trabajo y un loco amor por el juego. Él es el tipo que estará aquí para siempre, en todo lo relacionado con el beisbol... Ciertamente tiene una comprensión analítica de todo y una capacidad, simplemente por su inteligencia, pero creo que la combinación del entrenador y cómo ve las cosas aplicadas me llamó la atención”, declaró Aaron Boone a The Post. El nuevo encargado de analítica de los Yankees tiene varias cosas que mejorar. El equipo se ubicó la temporada pasada en el penúltimo sitio del Este de la Liga Americana con récord de 82-80. Una de las mayores deficiencia de los Bombarderos fue el bateo colectivo. Promediaron .207 para ubicarse en el penúltimo sitio de todo Major League Baseball, sólo por arriba de los Oakland Athletics. De OPS tuvieron .304. Leanhardt tiene un doctorado en física del MIT y pasó siete años como profesor de física en la Universidad de Michigan. Esta será su séptima temporada en la organización de los Yankees. ¿Será quien pueda romper con el ayuno de Serie Mundial ? title: Maluma emociona a sus fans con la llegada de su hija
text:
El artista colombiano Juan Luis Londoño Arias, reconocido como Maluma , ha sido el foco de los medios de comunicación nacionales e internacionales en los últimos meses, por el embarazo de su pareja Susana Gómez. Las tiernas fotos de Maluma junto a su pareja para empezar el 2024 El artista paisa ha estado bastante activo compartiendo imágenes del embarazo de su pareja mostrando su inmensa alegría por la próxima llegada de su primera primogénita, a quien llamarán París.
No dejes de leer
Maluma reveló cuál fue su reacción al enterarse que sería papá El hermoso gesto que tuvo la familia de Maluma en foto con su novia Precisamente, el artista decidió hacer su primera publicación del 2024 en donde compartió un carrusel de fotografías y un video al final en donde presumió a las personas más importantes de su vida y el embarazo de Susana.
Esto lo hizo a través de tiernas fotos en las que le daba besos a su pancita y también dejó una postal sentado desde la playa junto a un gran corazón que dibujó con el nombre de su hija. Haciendo alusión a su gran espera por la llegada de su bebé.
Asimismo, el cantante se dejó ver dándole un romántico beso a pareja, quien muestra su avanzado estado de embarazo, por lo que sus seguidores presumen que dentro de poco estaría dando a luz y no caben de la emoción.
¿Cuándo nacerá la hija de Maluma y Susana Gómez? Sin duda alguna, por las fotos del cantante paisa se prevé que dentro de pocas semanas su pareja esté dando a luz a su anhelada bebé. En los comentarios, sus seguidores se unieron a su emoción y le expresaron que están locos por conocer a esa bebé que de seguro acaparará todas las miradas y focos.
Maluma versión papá es el mejor; ya queremos conocer a París; esa bebé va a ser perfecta; Maluma está loco por su hija; qué bonito como presume a su pareja; Maluma se ve todo tierno sentado esperándola.

author: Harriet Ramos
title: Family remembers Mama Erma, Arlington woman killed in attack | Fort Worth Star-Telegram
text:
Arlington
‘Her legacy will live on:’ Family honors Arlington woman killed in random attack
Erma Adeyemo-Azeez loved God and people and left a lasting legacy in the lives of those she touched, her family said.
Adeyemo-Azeez was an ordained evangelist and passionate about winning souls for Christ, her daughter Kushana Allen told the Star-Telegram. She raised her children with integrity and the fear of the Lord.
The 63-year-old, affectionately known as “Mama Erma,” loved to help people, Allen said. On March 31 she was helping a friend move. She had just gotten back to her apartment complex in the 2600 block of Whisper Meadow Lane in Arlington when she was attacked and fatally stabbed.
Officers arrived at the scene shortly before midnight and found Adeyemo-Azeez lying unresponsive in a breezeway, police said. She was pronounced dead about 12:50 a.m. on April 1 at Arlington Memorial Hospital, according to the Tarrant County Medical Examiner.
Based on the investigation so far, Arlington police believe the attack on Adeyemo-Azeez — by a man released on bond after a previous violent crime — was random.
“I can’t even imagine why anyone would want to hurt her,” Allen said.
‘Mama Erma’ was a mother figure, mentor
Allen described Adeyemo-Azeez as a mother figure and mentor to countless individuals at her church and work. She loved to dance and could outrun people in their 20s, even while wearing her signature outfit of a dress, pantyhose and loafers.
“She was so full of life,” Allen said.
Adeyemo-Azeez spent more than 20 years teaching students with disabilities in Arlington ISD. According to the school district, she served as a special education assistant at Nichols Junior High.
“She was a valued long-time member of the district, and she had a significant impact on the lives of students before she left Arlington ISD several years ago,” the district said in a statement.
Adeyemo-Azeez worked as a receptionist at Texas Oncology after her retirement from Arlington ISD. She made friends with all the patients, according to Allen. Her primary job was scheduling patient appointments, but somehow she always ended up doing more for them, like calling an Uber or making sure they had something to eat.
“It was above and beyond in every single thing that she did,” Allen said.
Murder suspect was released on bond after robbery
Police arrested 23-year-old Jacob Arriaga Guerrero on April 1, and he is charged with murder in with Adeyemo-Azeez’s death.
Arriaga Guerrero had previously been arrested on March 23 after he was accused of stealing a pickup truck with a gun inside, robbing a woman at gunpoint at a Walmart in Crowley and leading officers on a car chase.
Following that arrest, Arriaga Guerrero was released March 28 on a $75,000 bond, according to Tarrant County court records. The conditions of his bond included wearing a GPS ankle monitor.
When Arlington police were investigating the stabbing on March 31, the Tarrant County Community Supervision and Corrections Department told detectives they’d received an ankle monitor tampering alert for Arriaga Guerrero. The Crowley man matched the description several witnesses gave of Adeyemo-Azeez’s attacker, and GPS data put him at the apartment complex at the time of the attack, police said.
By the time Arriaga Guerrero was arrested on April 1, he’d allegedly stolen a sport utility vehicle, hit a pedestrian walking a dog and collided with another vehicle at the intersection of Walnut Hill and Burney Road, police said.
Detectives in the Real Time Crime Center tracked down the SUV, police said. Officers responded to the location and arrested the driver, who was identified as Arriaga Guerrero, according to police.
Family believes justice system failed victim
Arriaga Guerrero is being held in the Tarrant County Jail on an increased bond of over $1.2 million. In addition to murder, he also faces charges of tampering with an electronic device, failing to identify as a fugitive from justice, theft, animal cruelty and a collision involving injury, according to jail records.
In the Crowley case, he faces charges of aggravated robbery, unauthorized use of a motor vehicle, evading arrest in a vehicle, unlawful carrying of a weapon and tampering with evidence.
Arriaga Guerrero’s attorney, Ray Hall Jr., told the Star-Telegram over the phone April 2 that the suspect’s family was concerned about his mental health and has been trying to get him evaluated.
A psychiatric exam was ordered for the suspect on Wednesday, April 9, according to court records.
“I can’t wrap my mind around why someone like that would be on the streets,” Allen said.
She said she doesn’t understand why the suspect was released on bond in the first place with all the pending charges against him in Crowley.
“This could have been prevented,” Allen said of her mother’s killing. “I don’t know why my mom had to pay the price for such negligence.”
Allen also questions why she and her family weren’t notified of her mother’s attack and death until several hours later.
Adeyemo-Azeez was scanned into Arlington Memorial Hospital as Jane Doe, according to Allen. If police had checked her ID, run her license plates or called the apartment complex’s emergency number they would have quickly learned her identity and could have contacted her family, she said.
Allen said she didn’t know anything was wrong until the apartment manager called in the morning to say her mom’s car was gone and was checking to make sure she was OK.
Allen became alarmed when her mother didn’t answer her phone and learned she hadn’t shown up for work. A friend who lived in the area went to check on Adeyemo-Azeez and told Allen police were at the apartment complex.
Allen called Arlington 911, and a dispatcher said they would call her back. Her mom’s apartment complex didn’t know where she had gone either. Allen said it was like her mom was missing.
An officer later called Allen’s sister to let her know their mom had been attacked and had died. According to Allen, they initially were told her mother’s death was most likely caused by a medical emergency because the stab wounds were superficial.
Arriaga Guerrero was initially charged with aggravated assault. The charge was upgraded to murder after the medical examiner ruled Adeyemo-Azeez’s death a homicide. According to the Medical Examiner’s Office website, Adeyemo-Azeez died from multiple stab wounds.
“There’s just so much gross negligence all the way around,” Allen said.
Even though Adeyemo-Azeez’s family believes the justice system failed her, they are choosing to focus on how she lived.
Her celebration of life service will be held Saturday, April 12, at 11 a.m. — the same time she was scheduled to work at her church’s food pantry.
“I’m glad her legacy will live on through us and everyone else she impacted,” Allen said.
Adeyemo-Azeez’s family has established a GoFundMe to help cover her funeral expenses.
This story was originally published April 9, 2025 at 4:41 PM.
